text:
Climate change is a fact. 
The Earth is a dynamic machine. 
It hosts a dynamic environment comprised of many parts...atmosphere, water, geologics, tectonic plates, molten core, etc. 
They are all influenced by more powerful forces like...the Sun.
Earth's climate has been changing since the Earth was born. 
So, yes...climate change is a fact. Just as electrons orbiting the nucleus of an atom is a fact.
Shit changes...everywhere.
The Enviroweenies decided to call it Climate Change because they were getting lampooned over the phrase Global Warming.
Pardon the pun but "Global Warming" wasn't 'sustainable'. Temperatures go up. Temperatures go down. 
Down too far, you get glaciers forming.
Up too far you get glaciers melting. 
It's been going on for a looooong fucking time. 
And it has been happening at intervals before there were any humans or internal combustion engines. 
Hundreds of millions of years. 
Man has no concept of geologic time scales. Or, at least, a very poor comprehension of it.

And lastly, let's say all the blather and doom saying is correct. We're doomed because the climate is changing. Fine.
What does anyone think can be done about it? Nothing. Such hubris.

Like Carlin said, "Save the Earth? The Earth will be just fine. The people are fucked."

text:
Any time I see somebody mindlessly parroting that 97% statistic, I know right away I am dealing with a person who is gullible and short on critical thinking skills.

Did anyone ever ask themselves from where that statistic came?

It came from a researcher named John Cook, who surveyed climate change research papers.

‚ÄúCook et al. (2013) found that over 97 percent [of papers he surveyed] endorsed the view that the Earth is warming up and human emissions of greenhouse gases are the main cause.‚Äù


Cook is able to demonstrate only that a relative handful endorse ‚Äúthe view that the Earth is warming up and human emissions of greenhouse gases are the main cause.‚Äù Cook calls this ‚Äúexplicit endorsement with quantification‚Äù (quantification meaning 50 percent or more). The problem is, only a small percentage of the papers fall into this category; Cook does not say what percentage, but when the study was publicly challenged by economist David Friedman, one observer calculated that only 1.6 percent explicitly stated that man-made greenhouse gases caused at least 50 percent of global warming.


Cook had created a category called ‚Äúexplicit endorsement without quantification‚Äù‚Äîthat is, papers in which the author, by Cook‚Äôs admission, did not say whether 1 percent or 50 percent or 100 percent of the warming was caused by man. He had also created a category called ‚Äúimplicit endorsement,‚Äù for papers that imply (but don‚Äôt say) that there is some man-made global warming and don‚Äôt quantify it. In other words, he created two categories that he labeled as endorsing a view that they most certainly didn‚Äôt.


The 97 percent claim is a deliberate misrepresentation designed to intimidate the public‚Äîand numerous scientists whose papers were classified by Cook protested:

‚ÄúCook survey included 10 of my 122 eligible papers. 5/10 were rated incorrectly. 4/5 were rated as endorse rather than neutral.‚Äù

‚ÄîDr. Richard Tol

‚ÄúThat is not an accurate representation of my paper . . .‚Äù

‚ÄîDr. Craig Idso

‚ÄúNope . . . it is not an accurate representation.‚Äù

‚ÄîDr. Nir Shaviv

‚ÄúCook et al. (2013) is based on a strawman argument . . .‚Äù

‚ÄîDr. Nicola Scafetta

text:
We've had "climate change" since the man crept from the caves as the glaciers began receding.   

That "96% of scientists" was a publication going through articles and attributing to the authors a support for (anthropogenic) climate change, and counting those authors, even when the authors themselves specifically objected and indicated they did not support (man-made) climate change!

Science does not advance by consensus; science has nothing whatsoever to do with populist consensus; that is going to give the populist socialist progressives nightmares. 

Back in 2000, the Mars Global Surveyor satellite recorded seeps coming from the southern faces of cliffs, scarps and impact craters.   More than a decade later NASA finally admitted those 'stains' were water.   Mars has no C02 being added to the environment by volcanism;  Mars has no rainfall recharging those aquifers; Mars has little atmosphere; Mars has no SUVs!  It's the sun, Stupid. 

Suddenly mankind, contributing only a minor percentage to the overall CO2 gains, is deemed causal to catastrophic positive feedback, and we have to return back to the caves to save the planet?  That is galactically stupid (I've always wanted to have a real reason to say that) .  The climate history shows, unmistakably, that atmospheric C02 concentration is actually a trailing effect of warming, not in anyway causal to that warming, much less causing catastrophic warming through positive feedback, not even on Venus! 

And for the record, I am a professional geologist and geophysicist, and this guy isn't even remotely funny. He's just Progressive Apparatchik Parrot trying to make a living.

author: malft

text:
¬†@malft¬†  That's the story, but not the history.  Copernicus brought heliocentrism to astronomy in the 1540s, long before Galileo's model of the solar system brought in elliptical orbits to replace the circular orbits of the then-current model; and a decade before he was even born.  Hell, the book he wrote comparing Ptolmeic geocentrism to Copernican heliocentrism was published over 15 years after the Roman Inquisition investigated him and his theories.

What Galileo got into trouble for was the fact that his "Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems" followed the tradition of a Socratic dialogue (wherein the new ideas are questioned by a secondary characters, allowing the writer's/ scientist's/ philosopher's self-insert character to describe relevant facets as answers to those questions,.  One of the questioners in Galileo used championed the theories and arguments of Ptolmeic geocentrism; but Galileo's characterization of him made him look like a complete and total idiot (And was, in fact, even named "Simplicio").

Normally, this would be dismissed as petty rivalry among competing theorists, but unfortunately that man who was being satirized was the Pope at the time  who, what with the Protestant Reformation just getting into full swing, was trying to smooth the ruffled feathers of the political factions within the Church by getting Galileo to at least include their geocentric, academically backsliding, beliefs in his book (Kind of like how GOP senators have to be given their opportunity to smear their "I'm no scientist, but..." feces all over what might otherwise turn into a discussion about reality with practical use to anyone involved.).  Needless to say, it didn't work out so well.

Then, the story got popularized by the Protestant side; lost quite a bit of accuracy in favour of becoming anti-Catholic propaganda; and turned into the "Galileo was the only Italian with the guts to stand up to the Papal morons!" bumper sticker we have today, as tends to happen whenever politics get involved...

text:
Marty T - There are a few experiments you can do at home to demonstrate that CO2 is a greenhouse gas:

1) Take two glass jars.  Fill one with regular air, and the other with CO2 (you can buy dry ice and melt it in the jar).  Put a thermometer in each jar and leave them both in the sun.  I think you know which one will be hotter after an hour or two.

2) Get two bottles of soda.  Put one in the fridge and the other in the sun for a few hours.  The warm bottle will overflow when you open it, but the cold one won‚Äôt.  That‚Äôs because warm water releases a lot of CO2, but cold water doesn‚Äôt.  The first jar experiment showed that CO2 traps heat.  The soda experiment shows how warm oceans release CO2 into the atmosphere.  I think you see how that would affect how warm the atmosphere gets from CO2 in the air.

You don‚Äôt have to trust scientists when you can prove global warming in your back yard.

text:
Gus Sandborg,
RE: the climate has change before.

It is true that the climate has changed before. We understand fairly well the mechanisms through which changes have occurred on the regional and global scales. Over the long-term (thousands of years) the earth's climate is controlled by orbital cycles which control the amount and seasonality of insolation received at the earth's surface (particularly at high latitudes). On shorter timescales solar variability and volcanism play a role - these combined factors and their resultant impacts on the oceans have lead to periodic warming events such as the Medieval Warm Period and the Little Ice Age. However, these natural factors are not the main causes of recent warming. We can be assured of this for two reasons - one, solar output has been declining since the ~1960s overall and two, volcanism has occurred often enough that it should have a substantial cooling impact on the earth's climate.

In contrast, we have a radiatively active greenhouse gas (CO2) which has been added to the atmosphere in ever increasing amounts. Satellite measurements can detect less heat escaping to space (e.g. an increasing greenhouse effect) and ground based measurements detect more longwave radiation hitting the surface of the earth. Beyond this today the satellite measurements are precise enough that we can actually evaluate which wavelengths are allowing heat to escape into space - overall there has been a substantial decrease in the amount of heat escaping to space at the wavelengths where CO2 is important.

That climate has changed before does not mean that climate change today cannot be anthropogenically driven - in fact it exemplifies how sensitive the climate can be.

If I can make a suggestion that may help you better understand climate change, I suggest that you read an introductory level and then a graduate level physical geography textbook - it may help you with understanding the key role that Greenhouse Gases have played throughout the Earth's history.

text:
Antarctic sea ice has been growing over the last few decades but it certainly is not due to cooling - the Southern Ocean has shown warming over same period. Increasing southern sea ice is due to a combination of complex phenomena including cyclonic winds around Antarctica and changes in ocean circulation.

The most common misconception regarding Antarctic sea ice is that sea ice is increasing because it's cooling around Antarctica. The reality is the Southern Ocean surrounding Antarctica has shown strong warming over the same period that sea ice has been increasing. Globally from 1955 to 1995, oceans have been warming at 0.1¬∞C per decade. In contrast, the Southern Ocean (specifically the region where Antarctic sea ice forms) has been warming at 0.17¬∞C per decade. Not only is the Southern Ocean warming, it's warming faster than the global trend. This warming trend is apparent in satellite measurements of temperature trends over Antarctica:
